record.title: Adaptive VR Systems Based on EEG and Machine Learning Algorithms

record.abstract: This paper presents a concept for a system that can adapt virtual reality (VR) scenes in real time based on the user's electroencephalographic (EEG) signals using machine learning algorithms. The proposed approach aims to increase the level of personalization and depth of immersion in the virtual environment by dynamically adjusting scene parameters according to the individual's emotional and cognitive state. The paper considers methods for EEG signal preprocessing, feature extraction, the use of modern neural network architectures for state classification, as well as mechanisms for mapping classification results onto visual and auditory VR elements. Potential applications are discussed, such as adaptive training simulators, therapeutic VR programs, games, and multimedia environments. Issues of scalability, the need for model personalization, minimizing processing delays, and possible solutions are also addressed. This work provides a theoretical foundation for future experimental research and the practical implementation of next-generation adaptive VR systems.
